Situation1: They notice their parents appear more stressed and tired than usual.
Situation2: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Story: The snow was coming down harder than I’d seen all winter, swirling in thick sheets across the windshield. My phone buzzed in the cupholder—Mom, again. I’d noticed the lines on her face deepening lately, the way Dad’s hands shook when he thought no one was looking. They needed me, just to talk, to listen, to be there. But in the back seat, my passenger kept glancing at his watch, anxiety radiating off him. He had to catch an international flight, and the roads were a mess. Every red light, every cautious turn, I felt his impatience grow. I was supposed to get him there safely and on time, but my mind kept drifting to home, to the worry in Mom’s voice. I gripped the wheel tighter, heart pounding, torn between the duty to my family and the responsibility to my passenger. The storm outside was nothing compared to the one inside me, as I tried to figure out who needed me more right now.
